matched.actualTitle: Remote Code Execution (RCE) via Unauthorized PHP Polyglot File Upload and Execution
matched.matchReason: Both findings address the same root vulnerability: insufficient file upload validation. The expected finding describes the validation bypass, while the actual finding demonstrates the impact of this bypass by showing that polyglot PHP files with valid JPEG headers can bypass magic number checks and be executed. The RCE finding directly results from the arbitrary file upload vulnerability.

matched.actualTitle: Remote Code Execution (RCE) via Unauthorized PHP Polyglot File Upload and Execution
matched.matchReason: The actual RCE finding demonstrates command injection via unsanitized user input in file handling operations. The POC shows execution of arbitrary system commands (id, whoami, cat /etc/passwd) through the uploaded PHP file, which directly corresponds to the expected command injection vulnerability in file upload handling.

extra.title: Stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in Image Filename Upload
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The application fails to properly HTML-encode uploaded filenames when displaying them in HTML attributes. While URL-encoded in responses, browsers decode these values, allowing stored XSS payloads to execute. This is a separate vulnerability from the expected findings and represents a genuine security issue that could be exploited for session hijacking and credential theft.

extra.title: Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) - Unauthorized File Access
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The application makes uploaded files directly accessible via HTTP without authentication or authorization checks. Files are stored with original filenames and can be accessed by anyone, allowing unauthorized information disclosure. This is a separate vulnerability from the expected file upload validation issues and represents a critical access control failure.

extra.title: CSRF Vulnerability - Missing CSRF Token on File Upload Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The file upload form lacks CSRF token protection and does not validate request origin. An attacker can trick users into uploading malicious files from external sites. This is a separate security control failure from the file upload validation issues.

extra.title: No Session Management - Arbitrary Session Cookies Accepted
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The application accepts arbitrary session identifiers without validation, enabling session fixation attacks. No server-side session management is implemented. This represents a fundamental authentication and authorization weakness.

extra.title: No Brute Force Protection on Public Endpoints
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The application does not implement rate limiting or account lockout mechanisms, allowing unlimited authentication attempts. This enables brute force attacks and credential enumeration.

extra.title: No Authentication Mechanism Implemented
extra.assessment: New discovery - critical vulnerability. The application has no login interface, credential verification, or access control. All endpoints are publicly accessible without any authentication. This is a fundamental architectural flaw that enables all other vulnerabilities.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Sensitive Server Details Exposed in Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The application exposes Apache version (2.4.54) and PHP version (7.4.33) through HTTP headers. While low severity, this aids reconnaissance and enables targeted exploitation of known CVEs.

extra.title: Missing Critical Security Headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP)
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The application is missing fundamental security headers that protect against clickjacking, MIME sniffing, and XSS attacks. This represents a security misconfiguration and defense-in-depth failure.

extra.title: No HTTPS/TLS Support - Unencrypted Communication
extra.assessment: New discovery - critical vulnerability. The application only supports HTTP on port 8080 with no HTTPS/TLS enabled. All communication is unencrypted, enabling man-in-the-middle attacks and eavesdropping on credentials and sensitive data.

extra.title: Missing Rate Limiting on File Upload Endpoint
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The file upload endpoint has no rate limiting, allowing unlimited concurrent uploads. This enables resource exhaustion and denial of service attacks.

extra.title: Information Disclosure via Publicly Accessible Metadata File
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The application stores and exposes metadata about uploaded files (uploaded.txt) in a web-accessible directory without authentication, leaking information about file upload patterns and user activity.

extra.title: Use of Outdated Software with Known Vulnerabilities
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate vulnerability. The application runs outdated versions of Apache (2.4.54, end-of-life June 2024) and PHP (7.4.33, end-of-life November 2022) with multiple documented CVEs. This creates direct attack vectors through known exploits and should be immediately patched.
